problems.title: NBHM 2005 - \int_{\Gamma } \frac{z \mathrm{d} z}{(z - 1)^4}
problems.problem:
Let $\Gamma $ be the circle in the complex plane with centre at $z = 1$ and of radius unity. Evaluate 
    \[
        \int_{\Gamma } \frac{z \mathrm{d} z}{(z - 1)^4}.
    \]
problems.hint: • Use Cauchy's integral formula.
problems.solution:
We will use Cauchy's integral formula to evaluate the integral over the circle $|z-1| = 1$ \[ \int_{\Gamma } \frac{z \mathrm{d} z}{(z - 1)^4}. \] By Cauchy's integral formula, \begin{align*} f^{(n)}(a) = \frac{n!}{2\pi \iota } \int_{\gamma } \frac{f(z)}{(z - a)^{n+1}} \mathrm{d} z, \end{align*} where $\gamma $be the circle $\vert z - z_0 \vert = r$, oriented counterclockwise and $a$ is any point in the interior of the disc $\vert z - z_0 \vert \leq r.$
Here $f(z) = z$, the disc is $\vert z - 1 \vert \leq 1$ and the point $a = 1$ which is in the interior of the disc. So, by Cauchy's integral formula, a \begin{align*} \int_{\Gamma } \frac{z \mathrm{d} z}{(z - 1)^4} & = \frac{2\pi \iota }{3!} \left[ \frac{\mathrm{d}^3}{\mathrm{d}z^3} (z) \right]_{z = 1} = 0. \end{align*}

problems.title: NBHM - 2005 - Pick out the functions from the following list which are analytic in C
problems.problem:
Pick out the functions from the following list which are analytic in $\mathbb{C} :$
  1. $f(z) = \vert z \vert ^2$
  2. $f(z) = \bar{z} $
  3. $f(z) = \text{ Re } (z)$.
problems.hint: • Apply the Cauchy-Riemann equations.
problems.solution:
Recall that if a complex function \[ f(z) = u(x,y) + \iota v(x,y), \] is analytic in a region $D$, then it must satisfy the Cauchy-Riemann equations, that is, \begin{align*} \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} = \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} \text{ and } \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} = - \frac{\partial v}{\partial x} \text{ on } D. \end{align*} This is equivalent to say that $\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z} } = 0 $ on $D$.
  1. The given function is $f(z) = \vert z \vert ^2 = z \bar{z}$. The function is not analytic in $\mathbb{C} $ as \[ \frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z} } = z \neq 0 \text{ on } \mathbb{C} . \]
  2. For the function $f(z) = \bar{z} $, \[ \frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z} } = 1 \neq 0 \text{ on } \mathbb{C}, \] and hence it is not analytic on $\mathbb{C} $.
  3. Recall that $\text{ Re } (z) = \frac{z + \bar{z}}{2}$, which is also not analytic on $\mathbb{C} $ as \[ \frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z} } (\text{ Re } (z)) = \frac{1}{2} \neq 0. \]

problems.title: NBHM 2005 - Is sin^2 z + cos^2 z = 1
problems.problem:
Pick out the statements which are true:
  1. $\vert \sin z \vert \leq 1$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C} $.
  2. $\sin ^2 z + \cos ^2 z = 1$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C} $.
  3. $\sin z = \frac{e^{\iota z} - e^{-\iota z}}{2}$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C} $.
problems.hint:
• Apply Liouville's theorem.
  • Note that $e^{\iota x} = \cos x + \iota \sin x$.
problems.solution:
1. Since $\sin z$ is an entire function, so using Liouville's theorem it can not be bounded as bounded entire function must be constant. Thus, the statement is FALSE.
  2. Again we will use Liouville's theorem. Since $\sin z$ and $\cos z$ both are entire functions, the function $\sin ^2 z + \cos ^2 z $ also be n entire function and hence it can not be bounded. Thus, $\sin ^2 z + \cos ^2 = 1$ is FALSE.
  3. Note that for $z = x + \iota y$, \begin{align*} e^{z} = e^x (\cos y + \iota \sin y) \implies e^{\iota x} = \cos x + \iota \sin x . \end{align*} Thus we have \begin{align*} e^{\iota z} & = \cos z + \iota \sin (z) \text{ and } e^{-\iota z} = \cos z - \iota \sin z. \end{align*} Thus, \begin{align*} \cos z = \frac{e^{\iota z} + e^{-\iota z}}{2} \text{ and } \sin z = \frac{e^{\iota z} - e^{-\iota z}}{2\iota }. \end{align*} Thus, the statement is FALSE.

problems.title: Solve \frac{z - 1}{z - \iota } = \frac{z + 2\iota }{z + 2}
problems.problem:
Solve 
    \[
        \frac{z - 1}{z - \iota } = \frac{z + 2\iota }{z + 2}.
    \]
    Also express it in $x + \iota y$ form.
problems.hint: • Easy simplification after cross multiplication.
problems.solution: Given that the equation is \begin{equation}\label{eq:27Jan2026-1} \frac{z - 1}{z - \iota } = \frac{z + 2\iota }{z + 2}. \end{equation} Note that \begin{align*} \frac{z - 1}{z - \iota } = \frac{z + 2\iota }{z + 2} & \implies (z - 1)(z+2) = (z + 2\iota ) (z - \iota ) \\ & \implies z^2 + z - 2 = z^2 + \iota z - 2 \iota ^2 \\ & \implies z - 2 = \iota z + 2 \\ & \implies z(1 - \iota ) = 4 \\ & \implies z = \frac{4}{1 - \iota }. \end{align*} Now to simply the above form, observe that \begin{align*} \frac{4}{1 - \iota } & = \frac{4}{1 - \iota } \times \frac{1 + \iota }{1 + \iota } = 4\frac{1 + \iota }{2} = 2 + 2 \iota . \end{align*}

problems.title: NBHM - 2006 - Find all possible values of the integral
problems.problem:
Let $\gamma $ be a closed continuously differentiable path in the upper half plane 
    \[
        \mathbb{H} = \{ z \in \mathbb{C} : z = x + \iota y,\  x , y \in \mathbb{R} \text{ and } y >0  \}
    \] 
    not passing through the point $\iota $. Describe the set of all possible values of the integral 
    \[
        \frac{1}{2\pi \iota } \int _{\gamma } \frac{2\iota }{z^2 + 1} \mathrm{d}z. 
    \]
problems.hint: • Note that $\gamma $ need not be a simple curve. Apply Residue theorem.
problems.solution:
We need to find all possible values of the integral \[ I \coloneqq \frac{1}{2\pi \iota } \int _{\gamma } \frac{2\iota }{z^2 + 1} \mathrm{d}z. \] Since $\gamma $ need not be simple closed cure, we will have the winding number of $\gamma $. We recall that by Residue theorem, \[ \int_\gamma f(z) \mathrm{d} z = 2\pi \iota \sum_{k=1}^{n} I(\gamma , a_k) \mathrm{Res}(f, a_k), \] where $f$ is holomorphic function on an open set $U \setminus \{ a_1, \dots, a_k \} $.
Here the function is $\frac{2\iota }{z^2 + 1}$, which has two possible singularities, $\pm \iota $. But, $-\iota $ does not lies in the upper half plane, so it has only one singularity (simple pole). So, we have the following two cases.
  1. Case-1: $\iota $ lies inside the curve $\gamma$, then \[ \mathrm{Res}(f, \iota ) = \lim_{z \to \iota }(z-\iota ) \frac{2\iota }{z^2 + 1} = 1. \] Thus, \begin{align*} I & = \frac{1}{2\pi \iota } \int _{\gamma } \frac{2\iota }{z^2 + 1} \mathrm{d}z \\ & = I(\gamma , \iota ). \end{align*} Since $I(\gamma ,\iota ) \in \mathbb{Z} $ thus the integral can take any integer value.
  2. Case-2: $\iota $ does not lie inside the curve $\gamma$. In this case, $f$ has no singularity inside $\gamma $ and hence there is no residue. So, $I = 0$.

problems.title: Cube root of z = -1 + \iota
problems.problem: Let $z = -1 + \iota $. Find the three cube roots of $z$.
problems.solution:
Given that $z = -1 + \iota$, we need to find the cube roots of $z$. First of all we write $z$ in terms of polar coordinates, that is, \[ z = \sqrt{2} \left(\cos \left( \frac{3\pi }{4} \right) + \iota \cos \left( \frac{3\pi }{4} \right) \right) = \sqrt{2} e^{3\pi /4} . \] The solution will be in the form of $z = r e^{\iota \theta }$, and we need to find $r$ and $\theta $.
We have \begin{align*} r^3 e^{3\iota \theta } = \sqrt{2} e^{3\pi /4} & \implies r = \sqrt[6]{2}, \text{ and } \\ & \quad \quad \quad 3\theta = \frac{3\pi}{4} + 2k \pi , k = 0,1,2 \\ & \implies \theta = \frac{\frac{3\pi}{4} + 2k\pi }{3}, k= 0,1,2. \end{align*} Thus, the cube roots are \[ z_1 = \sqrt[6]{2} e^{\pi /4}, \quad z_2 = \sqrt[6]{2} e^{11\pi /12}, \text{ and } z_3 = \sqrt[6]{2} e^{19\pi /12}. \]
